title: Are AI hiring tools to blame for job seekers being ghosted? Experts say it’s more complicated.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: AI hiring tools are often blamed for job seekers being ghosted, but experts point to a sluggish job market as the main issue.
Recruiters say AI systems are used mainly as filtering tools, and most resumes are still reviewed by humans at many companies.
The job market has cooled since the post-pandemic boom, with fewer urgent hirings, contributing to candidate frustrations.

title: Red Sox ace Garrett Crochet and wife Rachel announce birth of first child
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Garrett Crochet and wife Rachel announce the birth of their first child, Colette Spencer Crochet, on Instagram.
Garrett and Rachel Crochet have been together since college and married in 2021 before moving to Boston in 2024.
Crochet, a Red Sox pitcher, led the AL in innings and strikeouts and is under contract through 2031.

title: Local obituary: Bruce Higgins, 51, West Roxbury dad, prolific youth sports coach, and Boston cop
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Bruce Higgins Jr., 51, passed away on November 2, 2025, after a six-year battle with Melanoma.
Higgins served as a Boston police officer and detective, earning accolades such as the Trooper George L. Hanna Memorial Award.
He was a prolific youth sports coach and beloved community figure, leaving a significant impact on local kids' lives.

title: MSPCA-Angell appeals for help as pet food demand surges during SNAP hold
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: MSPCA-Angell is seeking donations as SNAP benefits suspension increases demand for pet food assistance in Massachusetts.
The nonprofit aims to distribute an additional 22,000 pet meals weekly, requiring $6,000 more per week.
Emergency pet food pantries are scheduled in November, including one on Nov. 13 at Nevins Farm in Methuen.

title: GBH lays off 15 employees in fourth wave of cuts this year
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: GBH laid off 15 employees in its fourth wave of cuts this year due to financial challenges.
The layoffs affected staff in content projects and roles like marketing, finance, and IT departments.
GBH has let go nearly 70 employees in 2025, driven by federal funding cuts and resulting revenue losses.

title: Police: Uber driver strangled with wire, carjacked in Boston
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Dorchester man Christopher Dawkins charged with carjacking, strangulation, and assault of an Uber driver in Boston.
Police tracked the stolen vehicle using the Uber driver's phone, which led to the suspect's arrest.
Uber banned the rider's account and is cooperating with law enforcement following the incident.

title: ‘It was obvious’: Lucas Giolito not surprised Red Sox didn’t extend him qualifying offer
author: Conor Roche
bullets: The Red Sox did not give Lucas Giolito a $22.05 million qualifying offer, despite his strong season.
Giolito, a free agent after declining a mutual option, missed the postseason due to elbow soreness.
Giolito expressed a desire to return to Boston, citing the 2025 season as the most enjoyable of his career.

title: Yellow and lime green, this $4.8M Provincetown house was an artists’ retreat: ‘A house with a soul’
author: Lindsay Crudele
bullets: Ronny Hazel's Provincetown home, known for its vibrant colors and artist contributions, is listed for sale at $4.8 million.
The house features artwork from local artists, a sculpture garden, and was often mistaken for a museum due to its unique decor.
Built in the 1870s, the 3,312-square-foot home has four bedrooms and offers waterviews and proximity to the beach.

title: Meet Jennifer Coolfridge — Brookline’s community fridge fighting food insecurity
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: The community fridge 'Jennifer Coolfridge' in Brookline supports residents facing food insecurity, especially after the EBT SNAP freeze.
Local groups like Brookline For the Culture and businesses such as Brothers and Sisters Cafe help maintain the fridge weekly.
Named after actress Jennifer Coolidge, the fridge accommodates dietary needs by excluding pork and nuts in its stocked items.

title: What the Patriots’ Carlton Davis said about returning to Tampa
author: Aidan Buchanan
bullets: Patriots cornerback Carlton Davis to return to Tampa Bay for the first time since being traded in 2024.
Davis played six seasons with the Buccaneers, earning 11 interceptions and a Super Bowl win in 2020.
Davis's veteran leadership has contributed to the Patriots' 7-2 record this season, says coach Justin Hamilton.
